author: ethdreamer
content:
So while implementing `capella` and reasoning about the `builder-spec` I realized we don't even need to transmit the `Withdrawal`s in the beacon blocks. I've made a PR to `consensus-specs` to discuss this.
https://github.com/ethereum/consensus-specs/pull/3092

author: jgm
content: `ExecutionPayloadHeader` only uses a root of withdrawals and not the list itself?  That's ugly.

author: jgm
content: How would a system that doesn't have direct access to state (_e.g._ Vouch) be able to obtain the withdrawals from the root?

author: sproul
content:
You could lookup the full block or sign the full block if desired (when not using a builder).

What do you imagine Vouch using the withdrawals for? Choosing between competing blocks?

author: potuz
content: that's a pretty unfair competition: at most one such block is valid

author: g11tech
content: we don't even need withdrawals root in the block üòÜ

author: g11tech
content: the payload's state root + beacon states balances (i.e. beacon's stateroot) 100% cover the withdrawal effects

author: jgm
content: How would the execution node know which balances to increment if the data is not in the execution payload?

author: sproul
content:
if the blocks are built on different parents they could have different withdrawals, but they‚Äôd likely also have very different attestations and the one attempting a re-org would probably pay more

not sure if Vouch considers this (yet)

author: sproul
content: there could be an ‚Äúextended payload‚Äù that contains the actual withdrawals, but it‚Äôs quite ugly from a spec PoV so IMO we should keep the withdrawals in the block

author: potuz
content: Oh lord I do hope that vouch is not playing with reorging üôÇ

author: g11tech
content: because the beacon node can calculate expected ~~balances~~ withdrawals and send to the engine

author: g11tech
content: they are totally derivable from the beacon state

author: jgm
content:
No, but we do have to suffer beacon nodes having differences of opinion.

As for looking up the full block, hard to do when it's still a proposal.

author: potuz
content: I think you guys must be talking about different things: the execution node surely needs the withdrawals to actually pay the ETH1 addresses

author: potuz
content: But is there an actual application for `vouch` knowing what are the withdrawals that will be included?

author: g11tech
content: yes, but it can be generated locally by the beacon node before it calls execution engine new payload

author: g11tech
content: using get expected withdrawals on the pre state

author: jgm
content: It allows us to sanity check the values.

author: g11tech
content: had some success in a lodestar<>geth, lodestar<>nethermind test , geth/nethermind seems to accept each others payloads so a +ve step

author: g11tech
content: thanks to <@412614104222531604> for persisting and testing out this configuration

author: g11tech
content: we verified that the validatorindex started from 0 (this lodestar image had latest spec changes) and looped back after some time

author: ralexstokes
content: it seems like a fine optimization to simply compare the hash tree root *but* i am pretty strongly against changing the spec in this way as it is a departure from what we 'expect' -- i.e. just having the data in the block

author: g11tech
content: we ( <@412614104222531604> + I ) just tested a full withdrawal

author: g11tech
content: and the balance updated 32 eth (though seems like validator still getting some rewards post withdrawal as we shortened the exit/withdraw ability window)

author: mariusvanderwijden
content:
For next tries to start the miner:
```
docker exec -it execution /bin/sh
geth attach eldata/geth.ipc
miner.setEtherbase("0xb02A2EdA1b317FBd16760128836B0Ac59B560e9D")
miner.start(1)
```

author: skylenet
content: Seems like "DOCKER" chain on iptables got nuked by something else. Restarting the docker daemon normally fixes this as it will set up this iptables chain on start. `systemctl restart docker`
